sections.content: Fields and Data Types
CRM offers multiple different types of fields. You can see **number**, **email**, **lookup**, **URL**, **phone**, and other types of fields being used by default.
CRM is **highly customizable**, giving you the ability to remove many of the default fields, and add a plethora of your own custom fields.
Some fields in CRM have default functions, like the **Company Name** field in Leads, and the **Stage** field in Deals.
Discussion: Understanding Critical Fields
Consider these questions about field customization:

items: If you remove the **Company Name** field from the Leads module, what happens?
Can you mimic this functionality any other way?
What are the implications of removing system fields versus custom fields?

sections.content: Layouts
Custom layouts allow you to tailor the CRM interface for different business scenarios and user needs.
Why Use Different Layouts?

items: **Contacts Module:** You might have one specific layout for your customers, while you have a different layout for a Vendor Contact
**Deals Module:** SMB layout might be smaller, with fewer fields for information, while for Mid-market or Enterprise Deals, you may need way more information, and therefore different layouts
**Field Sharing:** When using custom layouts, the fields are shared among each layout, and are either enabled or disabled, depending on the layout. All fields still exist inside the module as a whole
**Universal Availability:** All modules can have multiple layouts

sections.content: Activity: Create Your Own Custom Layout
Follow these steps to create and test a custom layout with your own fields.
Step 1: Navigate to Layout Settings

items: Within CRM, go to **Setup > Modules and Fields > Leads**
Click the **"New Layout"** button on the right side of the page
**Important:** Don't modify your default "Standard" layout at this point. We're creating a second one to preserve the factory settings as a reference point

sections.content: Step 2: Name Your Layout

items: In the top left, the layout will be titled "Untitled Layout"
Name this **"Break Me"** or **"Sandbox"** or something to indicate it's being used as your test layout

sections.content: Step 3: Add Custom Fields

items: Drag and drop fields into this layout that you think would be useful to know about Leads
Create **at least 3 custom fields** (more is better)
**Try to avoid the more complex fields for now**, like Formula Fields, Lookups, and Rollup Summary fields
Focus on simpler field types like Text, Number, Picklist, Date, Email, Phone, etc.

sections.content: Step 4: Set Access Permissions
When you save this layout, you'll be asked to set access permissions for who can see/use this layout:

items: **Administrator** will be populated already
You can add the **Standard** profile here if you wish
This controls which user profiles can access and use this layout

sections.content: Test Your New Layout and Fields
Now it's time to test your custom layout by creating new Lead records.
**Note:** None of your existing Leads will automatically be in this layout. You'll need to create new Leads or manually change the layout of existing ones.
Testing Instructions

items: Create a few new Leads
When creating, ensure that you select the layout you just created in the **"Layout"** field dropdown
Create **at least 3 Leads** using your custom layout
Fill the appropriate fields with information (including the custom fields you created)
**VERY IMPORTANT:** For at least one of the custom fields YOU CREATED, put the **same information** for all leads you create (we will use this later for filtering and reporting)

sections.content: Check Your Understanding
After completing this lesson, you should be able to:

items: Identify the different types of fields available in Zoho CRM
Understand the difference between system fields and custom fields
Create and configure custom layouts for different business scenarios
Add custom fields to layouts without affecting existing data
Set appropriate access permissions for custom layouts
Test and validate custom layouts by creating records
